section.title: Rolling Reboot of the Cloud
section.para: If you have a planned maintenance and need to bring down your entire cloud and restart services while minimizing downtime, follow the steps here to safely restart your cloud.

If you have a planned maintenance and need to bring down your entire cloud and restart services while minimizing downtime, follow the steps here to safely restart your cloud. If you don't mind your services being down, then another option for planned maintenance can be found at .

section.title: Recommended node reboot order
section.para: To ensure that rebooted nodes reintegrate into the cluster, the key is having enough time between controller reboots.
The recommended way to achieve this is as follows:

step.para: Reboot controller nodes one-by-one with a suitable interval in between. If you alternate between controllers and compute nodes you will gain more time between the controller reboots.
Reboot of compute nodes (if present in your cloud).
Reboot of Swift nodes (if present in your cloud).
Reboot of VSA nodes (if present in your cloud)
Reboot of Ceph nodes (if present in your cloud).
Reboot of ESX nodes (if present in your cloud).

section.title: Rebooting controller nodes
section.para: The first consideration before rebooting any controller nodes is that there are a few services that run as singletons (non-HA), thus they will be unavailable while the controller they run on is down. Typically this is a very small window, but if you want to retain the service during the reboot of that server you should take special action to maintain service, such as migrating the service.
For these steps, if your singleton services are running on controller1 and you move them to controller2, then ensure you move them back to controller1 before proceeding to reboot controller2.

section.title: Rebooting ceph
section.para: There are two categories of ceph nodes:
Ceph nodes should be rebooted in their position in the overall sequence described in the reboot order section above.
You should reboot both categories of ceph nodes in the order: monitor nodes, then OSD nodes. All ceph nodes should reboot one-by-one, in series.
If a monitor is deployed on controller node, then the rebooting sequence of the controller caters for the monitor nodes, so you need to additionally reboot only the OSD nodes.
If the monitor is deployed as a standalone; i.e., as separate set of resource nodes, you should reboot the monitor nodes before rebooting the OSD nodes.

For example, if there are three monitor nodes and three OSD nodes say, MON1, MON2 and MON3, with OSD1, OSD2, OSD3, then you should reboot MON1, then MON2 and then MON3 followed by OSD1, then OSD2 and so on In both cases, please ensure that you are serializing the reboot of a given family (monitor or OSD or controller); that is, don't reboot them all at the same time.
